qas.question: Which editor nearly ruined The Times in 1890?
Which energetic editor rescued The Times from financial collapse in 1890?
Which encyclopedia was The Times aggressively selling to American markets?
Who was the creator of the encyclopedia that The Times was known for selling to America?
Who later bought the well-known encyclopedia from The Times in 1908?

context: The Times faced financial extinction in 1890 under <a0_0>Arthur Fraser Walter<a0_0/>, but it was rescued by an energetic editor, <a1_0>Charles Frederic Moberly Bell<a1_0/>. During his tenure (1890–1911), The Times became associated with selling the Encyclopædia <a2_0>Britannica<a2_0/> using aggressive American marketing methods introduced by <a3_0>Horace Everett Hooper<a3_0/> and his advertising executive, Henry Haxton. Due to legal fights between the Britannica's two owners, Hooper and Walter Montgomery Jackson, The Times severed its connection in 1908 and was bought by pioneering newspaper magnate, <a4_0>Alfred Harmsworth<a4_0/>, later Lord Northcliffe.
